Clinical Presentation, Evaluation, and Management of Vaginitis
Cause of Vaginitis
Clinical Presentation
Evaluation
Management
Bacterial vaginosis
Malodorous or “fishy” vaginal discharge
Increased thin white or gray discharge
Symptoms other than malodor may be minimal
Diagnosis requires three of four findings (Amsel criteria):
Thin homogenous discharge
KOH amine whiff test result positive
Saline wet mount with >20% epithelial clue cells
Metronidazole: 500 mg orally twice daily for 7 days
a
(avoid alcohol during treatment and for 24 hours after last dose); or vaginal gel (0.75%) 5 g into vagina at bedtime for 5 nights
Clindamycin: vaginal cream (2%) 5 g into vagina for 7 nights
Sexual partners do not require treatment
Avoid sexual activity (or use condoms) during treatment
Vulvovaginal candidiasis
Itching, irritation, dysuria, dyspareunia, vulvodynia, excoriation, erythema, fissures
Increased thick white discharge
KOH amine whiff test result negative
KOH wet mount shows hyphae, pseudohyphae, or yeast
Uncomplicated
b
Over-the-Counter Intravaginal Agents
Clotrimazole: 1% cream 5 g intravaginally daily for 7–14 days; or 2% cream 5 g intravaginally daily for 3 days

Miconazole: 2% cream 5 g intravaginally daily for 7 days; or 4% cream 5 g intravaginally daily for 3 days; or 100-mg vaginal suppository, one suppository daily for 7 days; or 200-mg vaginal suppository, one suppository for 3 days; or 1,200- mg vaginal suppository, one suppository for 1 day
Tioconazole: 6.5% ointment 5 g intravaginally in a single application
Prescription Intravaginal Agents
Butoconazole: 2% cream (single-dose bioadhesive product) 5 g intravaginally in a single application
Terconazole: 0.4% cream 5 g intravaginally daily for 7 days; or 0.8% cream 5 g intravaginally daily for 3 days; or 80-mg vaginal suppository, one suppository daily for 3 days
Prescription Oral Agent
Fluconazole: 150 mg orally as a single dose
Complicated
c
Longer duration of initial oral or topical treatment, followed by maintenance therapy as needed:
Recurrent:
Fluconazole: 150 mg orally every 3 days for a total of three doses; or topical imidazole therapy for 7-14 nights
Maintenance therapy for refractory or recurrent symptoms:
Fluconazole: 150 mg orally weekly for 6 months
Severe:
Topical azole for 7-14 days or fluconazole 150mg for two doses separated by 72 hours
Non-albicans species:
Non-fluconazole topical azole for 7-14 days
Pregnancy:
Topical azole for 7 days; do not use fluconazole
Sexual partners do not require treatment
Trichomoniasis
Increased discolored discharge (yellowish, green, gray, and/or frothy)
Dyspareunia, dysuria, itch, erythema, postcoital bleeding
Punctate cervical hemorrhages (“strawberry” cervix)
KOH amine whiff test result negative
Saline wet mount with trichomonads, leukocytes
NAAT or rapid assay result positive
Metronidazole
a
: 500 mg orally twice daily for 7 days
Treatment of sexual partners is recommended to prevent reinfection; for men, metronidazole 2 g orally as a single dose

footnotes: KOH = potassium hydroxide; NAAT = nucleic acid amplification test.
